snippet.title: Crown building warchest but capital management not priority No.1, Citi says
snippet.content:
Crown Resorts will have up to $2 billion debt capacity in coming years, but that isn't necessarily a signal of near term capital management measures. Following Crown's annual results, Citi analysts reckon Crown's net debt will be worth only 0.2-times earnings come this time next year, and 0.5-times by the end of the 2020 financial year. That means $1.7 billion to $2 billion debt capacity, assuming a 2.5-times net debt-to-earnings limit. While those gearing forecasts are a sharp reduction on Crown's historical levels, Citi reckons shareholders should not expect a step-up in buybacks, special dividends and other capital management initiatives.
Instead, Crown seems to be preparing for a ramp up in capital expenditure for its expansion into Sydney worth $2.3 billion on a gross basis and $1.7 billion net of apartment sales, on Citi's numbers.
"We no longer anticipate further near term capital management for CWN in addition to the buyback," Citi analysts told clients following . Crown's result did include a $375 million odd on-market share buyback, however it was less than analysts and fund managers had expected.
